pullRequest.body:
Defines `MulAction.period g a` as a wrapper around `Function.minimalPeriod (fun x => g â€¢ x) a`,
allowing for some cleaner proofs involving the period of a group action.
The existing `MulAction.*_minimalPeriod_*` lemmas are changed to be defined using their now-preferred `MulAction.*_period_*` counterparts,
although they will only be made deprecated in another pull request.
The `Mathlib.GroupTheory.GroupAction.Period` module is also created, for additional lemmas around `MulAction.period`.

Some core lemmas need to remain in `Mathlib.Dynamics.PeriodicPts`, as they are needed for `ZMod` and the quotient group.

---

Note that the linter fails on `Mathlib.Dynamic.PeriodicPts`, since I do not know how to split the `to_additive` description on multiples lines :/

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go

- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

nodes.body:
> Note that the linter fails on Mathlib.Dynamic.PeriodicPts, since I do not know how to split the to_additive description on multiples lines :/

I think a newline without indentation works, i.e.
```
@[to_additive "foo
bar"]
def 
```
Oh it does, thanks
Fixed the style issues pointed out above :)

Couple of changes, as suggested; of interest:
- `le_period_of_moved` â†’ `le_period`
- `moved_of_lt_period` â†’ `pow_smul_ne_of_lt_period` (currently lives in the `MulAction` namespace)
- `period_eq_one_of_fixed` â†’ `period_eq_one_iff`
- new `period_one` and `period_inv` (I couldn't golf the latter any further)
- new `period_dvd_orderOf` and `period_dvd_exponent`, which helped golfed the rest of the lemmas
- added missing docstrings in `@[to_additive]`

```suggestion
  rw [period_eq_minimalPeriod, â† isPeriodicPt_iff_minimalPeriod_dvd, fixed_iff_isPeriodicPt]
```

```suggestion
  Â· rw [Int.negSucc_coe, zpow_neg, zpow_ofNat, inv_smul_eq_iff, eq_comm, dvd_neg, Int.coe_nat_dvd,
      pow_smul_eq_iff_period_dvd]
```
I think you can remove a lot of `Function.` thanks to this.
True, though I wonder if accidental name shadowing hasn't happened in the past
I think lean will complain about ambiguous names.

```suggestion
  conv_rhs => rw [â† Nat.mod_add_div n (period m a), pow_smul_plus_period]
```

```suggestion
  conv_rhs => rw [â† Int.emod_add_ediv j (period g a), zpow_smul_plus_period]
```
Why not use the new `period` definition here?
This is what `pow_smul_eq_iff_period_dvd` does above, these theorems are left here for compatibility purposes, since they're used in defining quotient groups, and will be made deprecated in #9514.
Ah, great.

Let's be slightly more precise (pedantic!).
```suggestion
The period of a multiplicative action of `g` on `a` is the smallest positive `n` such that
`g ^ n â€¢ a = a`, or `0` if such an `n` does not exist.
-/
@[to_additive "The period of an additive action of `g` on `a` is the smallest positive `n`
such that `(n â€¢ g) +áµ¥ a = a`, or `0` if such an `n` does not exist."]
```
This seems too general to be in this file: could you move it next to the declaration of `smul_iterate`?

A couple of tweaks:
 * Equalities tend to put the "more complicated" expressions on the left, for easier rewriting. So here `iterate` feels more complicated than exponentiation, so I've flipped the order.
 * With the flipped order comes a new name (I copied `smul_iterate`).
 * We have some neat notation for partially applying an operator by writing `Â·` for its arguments.
That gives:
```suggestion
@[to_additive]
lemma smul_iterate_apply (m : M) (a : Î±) (n : â„•) : (m â€¢ Â·)^[n] a  = m ^ n â€¢ a := by
  rw [smul_iterate]
```
It's unfortunate that `rw` doesn't provide an easy way to do eta-expansion for existing lemmas like `smul_iterate`

The naming convention suggests to put the binary operator `smul` after its left argument `pow_period`. I'd also leave out `fixed` since there is no definition `Fixed` to refer to. (Perhaps `pow_period_smul_eq_self` if you'd like to emphasize that it's kept fixed.)
```suggestion
theorem pow_period_smul (m : M) (a : Î±) : m ^ (period m a) â€¢ a = a := by
```

This lemma feels slightly on the trivial / overspecialized side but indeed there seems to be no good alternative way. I'd like to reverse its direction, though:
```suggestion
@[to_additive]
lemma isPeriodicPt_smul_iff {m : M} {a : Î±} {n : â„•} :
    IsPeriodicPt (fun x => m â€¢ x) n a â†” m ^ n â€¢ a = a := by
  rw [â† smul_iterate_apply, IsPeriodicPt, IsFixedPt]
```

```suggestion
theorem pow_smul_eq_iff_period_dvd {n : â„•} {m : M} {a : Î±} :
```

```suggestion
theorem zpow_smul_eq_iff_period_dvd {j : â„¤} {g : G} {a : Î±} :
```

I'd like to restructure this section somewhat: IMO the fundamental relation is that `m ^ k â€¢ a = m ^ n â€¢ a` if `n â‰¡ k` mod `period m a`. But we can't express that here because `Nat.ModEq` and `Int.ModEq` are not available, so the next best thing is to put the `mod` lemmas first.

Then I'm going to derive the addition results from them, and include addition on the left and on the right. Finally I'm renaming them since `+` is called `add` here, not `plus`. :)
```suggestion
@[to_additive (attr := simp)]
theorem pow_smul_mod_period (n : â„•) {m : M} {a : Î±}:
    m ^ (n % period m a) â€¢ a = m ^ n â€¢ a := by
  conv_rhs => rw [â† Nat.mod_add_div n (period m a), pow_add, mul_smul,
    pow_smul_eq_iff_period_dvd.mpr (dvd_mul_right _ _)]

@[to_additive (attr := simp)]
theorem zpow_smul_mod_period (j : â„¤) {g : G} {a : Î±}:
    g ^ (j % (period g a : â„¤)) â€¢ a = g ^ j â€¢ a := by
  conv_rhs => rw [â† Int.emod_add_ediv j (period g a), zpow_add, mul_smul,
    zpow_smul_eq_iff_period_dvd.mpr (dvd_mul_right _ _)]

@[to_additive (attr := simp)]
theorem pow_add_period_smul (n : â„•) (m : M) (a : Î±):
    m ^ (n + period m a) â€¢ a = m ^ n â€¢ a := by
  rw [â† pow_smul_mod_period, Nat.add_mod_right, pow_smul_mod_period]

@[to_additive (attr := simp)]
theorem pow_period_add_smul (n : â„•) (m : M) (a : Î±):
    m ^ (period m a + n) â€¢ a = m ^ n â€¢ a := by
  rw [â† pow_smul_mod_period, Nat.add_mod_left, pow_smul_mod_period]

@[to_additive (attr := simp)]
theorem zpow_add_period_smul (i : â„¤) (g : G) (a : Î±):
    g ^ (i + period g a) â€¢ a = g ^ i â€¢ a := by
  rw [â† zpow_smul_mod_period, Int.add_emod_self, zpow_smul_mod_period]

@[to_additive (attr := simp)]
theorem zpow_period_add_smul (i : â„¤) (g : G) (a : Î±):
    g ^ (period g a + i) â€¢ a = g ^ i â€¢ a := by
  rw [â† zpow_smul_mod_period, Int.add_emod_self_left, zpow_smul_mod_period]
```
Nice cleanup!

My hobby is sorting imports alphabetically :)
```suggestion
import Mathlib.Dynamics.PeriodicPts
import Mathlib.GroupTheory.Exponent
import Mathlib.GroupTheory.GroupAction.Basic
```
I should try to automate that :p

Theorem names really have to closely match their statement, so:
```suggestion
theorem le_period_of_moved {m : M} {a : Î±} {n : â„•} (period_pos : 0 < period m a)
```

(I assume "moved" is used as the opposite of "fixed (point)"? I'm not familiar with any word for this concept, so maybe another name would be clearer for other users too.)
To be fair, this is the only real mechanism to prove a lower bound for the period, so we could just go with `le_period`

`by_contra!` can do some of the rewrites for you automatically:
```suggestion
  by_contra! period_lt_n
  apply moved _ period_pos period_lt_n
  exact smul_pow_period_fixed m a
```

In fact if you really love term mode this could even become:
```suggestion
  le_of_not_gt <| fun period_lt_n => moved _ period_pos period_lt_n <| smul_pow_period_fixed m a
```
(although I would not advise it!)

Here I would not go into tactic mode:
```suggestion
    period m a â‰¤ n :=
  (isPeriodicPt_smul_iff.mpr fixed).minimalPeriod_le n_pos
```

Idem:
```suggestion
    0 < period m a :=
  (isPeriodicPt_smul_iff.mpr fixed).minimalPeriod_pos n_pos
```

There's a little trick here: for `n : â„•`, `0 < n` is definitionally equal to `1 â‰¤ n`.
```suggestion
theorem period_eq_one_of_fixed {m : M} {a : Î±} (fixed : m â€¢ a = a) : period m a = 1 := :=
  le_antisymm
    (period_le_of_fixed one_pos (by simpa))
    (period_pos_of_fixed one_pos (by simpa))
```

A less tricky way is to use `linarith` to figure out the equality:
```suggestion
theorem period_eq_one_of_fixed {m : M} {a : Î±} (fixed : m â€¢ a = a) : period m a = 1 := by
  have : period m a â‰¤ 1 := period_le_of_fixed one_pos (by simpa)
  have : 0 < period m a := period_pos_of_fixed one_pos (by simpa)
  linarith
```

All these tactic steps can also be term steps. I'd also like to replace the specific `Nat.not_le` with a more general `not_le_of_gt`.
```suggestion
    m^n â€¢ a â‰  a :=
  fun a_fixed => not_le_of_gt n_lt_period (period_le_of_fixed n_pos a_fixed)
```

Following a plain `simp` with another tactic ("non-terminal `simp`") is dangerous since the set of `simp` lemmas can change and break the proof. `simp` followed by `apply`/`exact` can often be combined into `simpa` instead:
```suggestion
  simpa [upperBounds] using period_le_exponent exp_pos _
```
I think we should add a few more lemmas about special cases of `period`, in particular `period_one : period 1 x = 1` and `period_inv : period gâ»Â¹ x = period g x`? (Assuming those are correct!)

Good point about `to_additive`izing the doc comments, let's not forget this one!
```suggestion
/-- `MulAction.period m a` is definitionally equal to `Function.minimalPeriod (m â€¢ Â·) a`. -/
@[to_additive "`AddAction.period m a` is definitionally equal to `Function.minimalPeriod (m +áµ¥ Â·) a`"]
```

For some reason the style guide says brackets belong on the next line, even if it makes indentation look slightly ugly.
```suggestion
theorem period_eq_one_iff {m : M} {a : Î±} : period m a = 1 â†” m â€¢ a = a :=
  âŸ¨fun eq_one => pow_one m â–¸ eq_one â–¸ pow_period_smul m a,
   fun fixed => le_antisymm
    (period_le_of_fixed one_pos (by simpa))
    (period_pos_of_fixed one_pos (by simpa))âŸ©
```

Couple of changes, as suggested; of interest:
- `le_period_of_moved` â†’ `le_period`
- `moved_of_lt_period` â†’ `pow_smul_ne_of_lt_period` (currently lives in the `MulAction` namespace)
- `period_eq_one_of_fixed` â†’ `period_eq_one_iff`

- new `period_dvd_orderOf` and `period_dvd_exponent`, which helped golfed the rest of the lemmas
- added missing docstrings in `@[to_additive]`

Some minor comments and I'm happy with this, thanks! I'm going to ask another maintainer to delegate this because I haven't reviewed `Dynamics` before and I contributed a few of the lemmas.
